column1: Circles of the World was a general term that seems to refer to the boundaries between the World and the Void
column2: though its usage is vague and does not seem to be completely consistent.
it appears to be a completely inclusive term
column3: describing the entirety of the World and its surrounding seas and airs
column4: and explicitly including the Undying Lands of Aman. The region beyond the Circles is then the place where Ilúvatar dwells (presumably with those of the Ainur who did not descend into Arda). Maedhros fears that because of the Oath of Fëanor
column5: their may no longer be able to "reach to Ilúvatar beyond the Circles of the World".

column1: It is the fate of Men to pass out of the Circles of the World after death. Aragorn refers to the Circles of the World to Arwen at his death
column2: saying that they were not bound forever to the Circles of the World
column3: and would meet again. A similar phrase occurs in the story of Beren and Lúthien
column4: where it is said their paths "led together beyond the confines of the world".

column3: went to war with the Valar
column4: expecting to obtain "everlasting life within the Circles of the World".

column1: Further to the Downfall of Númenor
column2: the term apparently took a more narrow meaning. After the Changing of the World
column3: and the taking away of Aman
column4: the lands of the Uttermost West are said to be no longer within the Circles of the World
column5: though they are clearly still part of the World in some sense. After this point
column6: it seems that the Circles of the World are simply the boundaries of the Mortal Lands of Middle-earth. Notably
column7: the choice is eventually offered to the children of Elrond
column8: either to become mortal or "to pass with him from the circle of the world". More generally
column11: are said to "dwell now beyond the circles of the world".

column1: Jason Fisher identifies possible sources for this phrase in the Norse kringla heimsins ("circle of the world" in the http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heimskringla Heimskringla)
column2: the Latin orbis terrarum (notably found in the Vulgate
column3: and particularly in the Book of Wisdom)
column4: and the design of medieval T-O maps such as the mappa mundi of Hereford (where the circular world-map is surrounded by the letters M
column8: "Sourcing Tolkien’s “Circles of the World”: Speculations on the Heimskringla
column10: and the Hereford Mappa Mundi" in Middle-earth and Beyond
